newsitem.title: MEXICO: Serfin said in talks with HSBC. [CORRECTED 15:40 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Serfin said in talks with HSBC. [CORRECTED 15:40 GMT]

text.p: Grupo Financiero Serfin, Mexico's third largest banking group, is discussing with HSBC Holdings the sale of up to 20 percent of its equity, Mexican banking sources said on Tuesday.
However, a Serfin spokesman denied a report by Mexican state-run news agency Notimex that London-based HSBC had already agreed to buy a stake in Serfin.
"As of today, nothing has been agreed," the spokesman, who asked not to be identified, said.
Serfin has said it is seeking a foreign partner by mid-1997, and it has engaged J.P. Morgan to carry out the search. The partner is expected to buy Serfin debentures held by J.P Morgan.
Serfin was one of the banks hardest hit by Mexico's bad-loan crisis in the aftermath of the 1994-5 peso devaluation.

On Tuesday it announced the sale of its guarantee unit, Afianzadora Insurgentes Serfin SA, to United States Fidelity and Guaranty Co for $65 million, that completed 66 percent of the banking group's recapitalization program.

Foreign banks, chiefly from Spain, have been making a strong incursion into the Mexican banking sector this year, buying up trouble-struck banks at prices that analysts say are cheap because of the lingering effects of the crisis.
